question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What official position did Luis Muñoz de Guzmán hold last before 2000?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
Luis Muñoz de Guzmán

Luis Muñoz de Guzmán was a Spanish colonial administrator who held the position of Royal Governor of Chile from 1749 to 1768. Early Life and Career

Luis Muñoz de Guzmán was born in 1705 in Spain. Little is known about his early life, but it is recorded that he came from a noble family. He began his career in the Spanish colonial administration, serving in various positions in the Americas. Royal Governor of Chile

In 1749, Muñoz de Guzmán was appointed as the Royal Governor of Chile by King Ferdinand VI of Spain. This position was one of the highest-ranking administrative posts in the Spanish colonies in South America. As Royal Governor, Muñoz de Guzmán was responsible for governing the Captaincy General of Chile, which included the provinces of Santiago, Concepción, and Valdivia. During his tenure, Muñoz de Guzmán implemented several reforms aimed at modernizing the colonial administration and improving the economy of Chile. He also worked to strengthen the defenses of the colony against the threat of indigenous attacks and British piracy. Muñoz de Guzmán's administration was marked by several significant events, including the establishment of the first postal service in Chile and the construction of the Royal Road, which connected Santiago to the port city of Valparaíso. References

* "Luis Muñoz de Guzmán" in Diccionario Biográfico Español (Spanish Biographical Dictionary), Real Academia de la Historia (Royal Academy of History), 2011. * "Royal Governors of Chile" in Historia de Chile (History of Chile), Editorial Universitaria, 2015. * "Luis Muñoz de Guzmán, gobernador de Chile (1749-1768)" (Luis Muñoz de Guzmán, Governor of Chile (1749-1768)) in Revista de Estudios Históricos (Journal of Historical Studies), Universidad de Chile, 2018. Royal Governor of Chile

The Royal Governor of Chile was a Spanish colonial administrator position established in the 16th century. The position was created by the Spanish Crown to govern the Captaincy General of Chile, which was a territorial entity that included the provinces of Santiago, Concepción, and Valdivia.
content.source_2: In the year 2025, the world was on the cusp of a new era of technological advancements and societal shifts. As the effects of climate change and economic inequality continued to shape the global landscape, the people of France looked to their leaders for guidance and solutions. It was on June 3rd of that year that Luis Muñoz de Guzmán, a seasoned politician with a background in labor rights, was appointed as the Minister of Labour. At the time, Muñoz de Guzmán was a relatively unknown figure outside of Chile, where he had served as Royal Governor. However, his reputation as a champion of workers' rights and his ability to navigate complex political landscapes had caught the attention of the French government. As he took office, Muñoz de Guzmán was tasked with addressing the growing concerns of the French working class, who felt increasingly disenfranchised by the rapid pace of automation and globalization. Over the next 14 years, Muñoz de Guzmán worked tirelessly to implement policies that protected the rights of workers while also promoting economic growth and innovation. He oversaw the passage of landmark legislation, such as the "Future of Work Act," which provided training and education programs for workers displaced by automation. He also established the "National Labour Council," a body that brought together representatives from industry, government, and labor unions to address the challenges of the modern workforce. As the years passed, Muñoz de Guzmán's reputation as a visionary leader grew. He became known for his ability to bring people together, to find common ground between seemingly intractable opponents. His commitment to social justice and his willingness to listen to the concerns of all stakeholders earned him the respect of his peers and the admiration of the French people. But as the years went by, Muñoz de Guzmán began to feel the weight of his responsibilities. The challenges of the modern world were relentless, and the demands on his time and energy were exhausting. He knew that he couldn't continue in the role indefinitely, and so, on December 18th, 2039, he tendered his resignation as Minister of Labour. As he looked back on his time in office, Muñoz de Guzmán felt a sense of pride and accomplishment. He had made a difference, he had left a mark on the world.
